title-group.article-title: Interfacial effect on the electromechanical behaviors of piezoelectric/elastic composite smart beams

contrib-group.aff: Department of Engineering Mechanics, Institution of Applied Mechanics, School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Huiming Wang, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Institution of Applied Mechanics, School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, People’s Republic of China. Email: wanghuiming@zju.edu.cn

abstract.p: An efficient electromechanical coupling model is developed to analyze the effect of the interfacial properties on the mechanical behaviors of piezoelectric/elastic composite smart beams. The interface of the composite smart beams is assumed to be imperfectly bonded and is modeled by the shear-lag model. An asymptotic expansion approximation is employed to construct the electric potential distribution in the piezoelectric layer. The governing equation is derived for the piezoelectric/elastic composite smart beams taking into account the electromechanical coupling effect and the interfacial imperfection. In the numerical analysis, both the mechanical and the electrical loadings are considered. The mechanical behaviors of the composite smart beams are illustrated graphically for three types of boundary conditions: (a) clamped supported–freely supported (C-F), (b) clamped supported–hinged supported (C-H), and (c) hinged supported–hinged supported (H-H). The results show that the interfacial properties have significant effect on the mechanical behaviors of the piezoelectric/elastic composite smart beams. For mechanically actuated case, a larger interfacial imperfection causes a larger transverse deflection, while it is contrary for electrically actuated case.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to the advantages of the intrinsic strong electromechanical coupling effect and the fast response, piezoelectric materials have been widely used in various smart systems and structures for the purpose of sensing or actuating (Anton and Sodano, 2007; Irschik, 2002; Tressler et al., 1998). In order to improve the electromechanical coupling behaviors or fulfill the function of optimization of the piezoelectric smart element, the integrated systems with different materials resulting in layered or laminated composite structures are widely used in the engineering practices (Akdogan et al., 2005; Chee et al., 1998). Through the precision design, the integrated systems can exhibit amazing performances.

Beam-like structures are one of the common configurations in engineering and microelectromechanical system (MEMS) applications. For instance, the piezoelectric unimorph and bimorph cantilevers have been widely employed in the piezoelectric energy harvester systems (Dietl et al., 2010; Erturk and Inman, 2008; Jiang et al., 2005; Mo et al., 2009), microactuators (Fu et al., 2006), and biosensors (Yi et al., 2002). Recently, an important application of the piezoelectric composite cantilevered beam has also been explored in measuring the elastic modulus of the soft materials or tissues (Szewczyk et al., 2006).

Many investigations have been reported to investigate the electromechanical behaviors of the piezoelectric composite beams. Huang et al. (2004) studied the tip deflection of a piezoelectric bimorph cantilever in the static state. The electromechanical analysis of an asymmetric piezoelectric/elastic laminate structure was performed by Chang and Chou (1999). Xiang and Shi (2008) carried out the static analysis for multilayered piezoelectric cantilevers. Wang et al. (2007a) developed an analytical model of a piezoelectric composite beam based on the third-order displacement theory. Some works have also been performed for the electrostatic analysis of the functionally graded piezoelectric beams (Huang et al., 2008; Xiang and Shi, 2007).

Most of the works in this area are focused on the piezoelectric composite beams, which are perfectly bonded at the interface. In this case, the elastic and the electric fields at the interface are assumed to be continuous. While in practice, the bond between two different materials may be either weakened in the process of manufacture due to the involvement of small microcracks and inhomogeneities or damaged in the severe loading conditions (Chen and Lee, 2005). In the open literatures, the shear-lag model (Chen and Lee, 2005; Li and Lee, 2009; Wang et al., 2007b) has been widely used to simulate the electromechanical defect of an interface.

To capture the effect of the interfacial properties on the electromechanical behaviors of the piezoelectric composites, an analytical model is always required. In this investigation, based on the shear-lag model, an analytical model is developed for analyzing the electromechanical behaviors of a piezoelectric/elastic composite beam taking into consideration the interfacial properties. Using this model, a numerical analysis is performed for the piezoelectric/elastic composite beams undergoing the mechanical and electrical loads.

sec.title: Shear-lag model
sec.p: Consider a piezoelectric composite smart beam of length L, width B, and height H, as shown in Figure 1. The beam consists of a piezoelectric layer of height hp and an elastic substrate of height he. Denote h=H/2=(hp+he)/2 as the distance between the centroids of the cross sections of the piezoelectric layer and the elastic substrate. The piezoelectric layer is polarized in thickness direction and covered by the very thin electrodes on its top and bottom surfaces. The smart beam can be actuated by applying a distributed loading q on the top surface of the beam or an external voltage V between the two electrodes.

sec.p: Suppose the interface between the piezoelectric and the elastic layers is not perfectly bonded. Define us as the interlayer displacement slip and T the interlaminar shear force. By introducing an interfacial parameter χ, the shear-lag model is then read as

where χ is a constant that denotes the degree of the interfacial imperfection. The larger the χ, the weaker the connection at the interface. Consider two limiting cases: (1) χ = 0 corresponds to us=0, which means that the interface is perfectly bonded, and (2) χ = ∞ corresponds to T = 0, which means that the interface is smooth contact. In the international system of units (SI), the unit of force is Newton (N) and length is meter (m). The interfacial parameter χ denotes the interlaminar slip under the shear force of 1 N. In engineering practice, when the composite beam elements are connected by the concentrated mechanical shear connections such as bolts and nails, the interfacial properties can be modeled by the shear-lag model (Adam et al., 1997).

sec.title: Numerical results
sec.p: Several numerical examples are performed to demonstrate the applications of the presented solution. The composite smart beam is composed of a PZT-5A layer and an aluminum substrate. The material properties are listed as (Krommer and Irschik, 2002): s11E=16.4×10−12m2/N, ∈33σ=1700∈0(∈0=8.85×10−12F/m), d31=−171×10−12C/N, and Ee=70GPa. The geometric parameters of the composite beam are set as L = 100 mm, B = 10 mm, and H = 5 mm. Three types of boundary conditions will be considered. Specifically, (1) one end is clamped supported and the other end is freely supported (C-F), also named as cantilevered beam; (2) one end is clamped supported and the other end is hinged supported (C-H); (3) both the ends are hinged supported (H-H). sec.title: Voltage excitation
sec.p: In this example, the thickness ratio is fixed as hp/he=1/4. The top electrode of the piezoelectric layer is subjected to a constant voltage −1000 V and the bottom electrode is electrically shorted. Figure 3 shows the distributions of the transverse deflection of the PZT-5A/aluminum composite smart beams along the longitudinal direction for three types of the boundary conditions when actuated by a voltage excitation. In order to show the effect of the interfacial parameter on the mechanical behaviors, five values of η are considered. Let η = 0 (perfectly bonded), 102, 103, 104, and ∞ (smooth contact). From Figure 3, we note that under the same boundary conditions, the maximum transverse deflection appears at η = 0 and decreases with the increase of η. The physical interpretation is that with the increase of η, the coupling effect between the PZT-5A layer and the aluminum substrate becomes weaker and weaker, and the voltage-induced actuation in the PZT-5A layer cannot completely pass into the aluminum substrate through the interfacial interaction. The distributions of the axial strain along the thickness direction are depicted in Figure 4. The selected cross sections are x = 0L for C-F and x = 0.5L for both C-H and H-H. For η = 0, the distributions of the axial strain along the thickness direction for three types of the boundary conditions are straight lines. For imperfectly bonded case, a jump of the axial strain is then observed at the interface. While in each individual layer, the distributions of the axial strain keep straight lines.

sec.title: Mechanical loading
sec.p: In this example, the thickness ratio is also fixed as hp/he=1/4. Both the top and the bottom electrodes of the PZT-5A layer are electrically shorted. The composite smart beam is subjected to a uniformly distributed loading q0=−100N/m. Figure 5 illustrates the distributions of the transverse deflection along the longitudinal direction for three types of the boundary conditions. Different from Figure 3, the maximum transverse deflection appears at η = ∞ and decreases with the decrease of η. For uniformly distributed loading, the actuation in the PZT-5A layer can be passed into the aluminum substrate through the normal stress interaction at the interface in spite of the existence of the interfacial imperfections. The larger the η, the smaller the bending stiffness of the composite beam. Figure 6 depicts the distributions of the axial strain along the thickness direction at the selected cross sections x = 0L for C-F and x = 0.5L for both C-H and H-H. The similar behaviors with those in Figure 4 can be observed in Figure 6.

sec.title: Effect of the thickness of the piezoelectric layer
sec.p: Figure 7 shows the transverse deflection of the cantilevered PZT-5A/aluminum composite beam at the free end as a function of interfacial parameter for three different thickness ratios of the PZT-5A layer to aluminum substrate hp/he=1/5,1/4,and1/3. Figure 7(a) is for the voltage excitation −1000 V and Figure 7(b) is for the uniformly distributed loading q0=−100N/m. From Figure 7(a), we can see that for a fixed thickness ratio, the voltage-induced transverse deflection decreases with the increase of η. At a fixed η, the voltage-induced transverse deflection decreases with the increase of thickness ratio hp/he. The reason is that for a thinner PZT-5A layer, the constant voltage corresponds to a larger electric field and induces a larger eccentric bending moment. From Figure 7(b), we can see that for a fixed thickness ratio, the uniformly distributed loading actuated transverse deflection increases with the increase of η. At a fixed η, the uniformly distributed loading actuated transverse deflection increases with the increase of thickness ratio hp/he. Figure 7 also shows that for both the electrical and mechanical loadings, the transverse deflection has a sensitive range for the interfacial parameter. This range shown in Figure 7 is observed as η∈[102~104].

sec.title: Validation
sec.p: The validity of the present method is performed in this section. The transverse deflection for a perfectly bonded composite beam consisted of a PZT-5A layer and a graphite/epoxy substrate is obtained by the present method and the finite element method (FEM). The geometrical parameters are same as those employed by Wang et al. (2007a). Table 1 lists the transverse deflection of a cantilevered composite beam actuated by a voltage of 100 V on the top electrode. Tables 2 and 3 show the transverse deflection for C-C and C-H composite beams actuated by the uniformly distributed loading q0=−10N/m. For the uniformly distributed loading case, both the top and the bottom electrodes of the PZT-5A layer are electrically shorted. Good agreement is achieved as presented in Tables 1 to 3, and the validity of the present method is then verified.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The electromechanical coupling analysis is carried out for a PECS beam taking into account the interfacial imperfection. A sixth-order governing equation is derived, and the analytical solution is obtained. For both the mechanical and voltage actuated cases, numerical results show that the interfacial properties have significant effect on the mechanical behaviors of the composite smart beams. The potential applications of the present analysis can be found in evaluating the performance of the piezoelectric/elastic composite beam type actuators and sensors with imperfectly bonded interfaces. This investigation also provides a feasible way in detecting the interfacial properties based on the electromechanical coupling analysis.
